results.title: Ascendancy
results.creator_credit: BFI, Penny Clark, Ian Elsey and Edward Bennett
results.brief_description: Ireland 1920. Rebellion against British rule is gathering force. Belfast is ominously quiet. Safe inside her fathers mansion, Connie (Julie Covington), is protected from the world. Her father manages the shipyard responsible for the family fortune while she is treated for a severely paralysed arm, an hysterical ailment connected to her brothers’ death during the Great War. Connie, oblivious to the looming crisis wanders dreamily around her brother’s room while the city erupts in bitter rioting. Even the household is affected when Connie’s maid, a Catholic, is driven out by the Protestant servants. British troops arrive and some of the officers are invited to a tea-party where Connie meets young Lieutenant Ryder (Ian Charleson) who has a profound effect upon her, shattering her fantasies of war and forcing her to confront its terrible reality. Co-starring John Phillips and Susan Engel. FilmFest Berlin 1983 Golden Bear-Best Film.

results.title: As young as you feel
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Lamar Trotti and Harmon Jones
results.brief_description: John Hodges (Monty Woolley) is a printer for the Acme Printing Company, who in turn are owned through various sub-siduaries by Consolidated Motors. This is where our problem begins… Consolidated Motors has a Personnel Policy stating “All workers over 65 have to retire”, and our John Hodges does not want to be forcibly retired and wants his job back. He wishes to fight for the principle of dignity - both in life and at work. “There is more to life than mere success” he attests, but how does he go about this courageous though some may say futile enterprise? He dyes his hair black and pays a visit to the offices of Mr McKinley, manager at Acme Printing, where he meets Marilyn Monroe as the company secretary in one of her first and funniest roles. Posing as President of Consolidated Motors in order to get the policy overturned, he finds himself feted and listened to as a elder statesman of the Business World. Cast also includes Thelma Ritter, David Wayne, Jean Peters, Constance Bennett and many others who give stirling performances, also includes a very young Russ Tamblyn.

results.title: As you like it
results.creator_credit: BBC, Time-Life Films, Cedric Messina and Basil Coleman
results.brief_description: Orlando is forced to flee to the forest to escape the evil plots of his jealous brother, Oliver. Rosalind incurs her uncle’s wrath and also flees to the forest, accompanied by Celia and Touchstone the clown. Disguised as a youth known as Ganymede, Rosalind meets Orlando who confides his love for Rosalind to Ganymede (Rosalind). Oliver arrives in the forest and is saved from certain death by Orlando and the two brothers are reconciled. Oliver woos Celia, Touchstone woos the dullwitted Audrey, Silvius (a shepherd) woos Phoebe and Phoebe woos the disguised Rosalind who finally reveals her identity to Orlando. The four pairs of lovers are united in the feast of Hymen.

results.title: As we talk we learn (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, Malcolm Smith and Brian Bergin
results.brief_description: Language, specifically talking, is a valuable, perhaps essential element in processes of learning. This film looks at communication between teacher and pupil is necessary in order to maximize the learning process. Various kinds of classroom talking are illustrated in order to determine which is the most effective technique for learning.

results.title: As usual = Sens devant derriere
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Paul Larose, Monique Letourneau and Raymond Brousseau
results.brief_description: Imagine a world where everything moves backwards. That is what happens in this experimental film without words when a man wakes up to the sound of his alarm clock and begins his day, only to find that for some mysterious reason everything is running in reverse - his electric shaver, the morning paper. Out in the street, people and cars are backing away. He alone of all the crowd seems to move forward normally. The effect on him and the viewers verges on the bizarre. Sound film without commentary.

results.title: As time goes by
results.creator_credit: Valhalla, Chris Kiely and Barry Peak
results.brief_description: Science fiction comedy about a bizarre encounter between a knockabout surfer and an alien, set in the Australian outback. The alien enlists the surfer’s aid in finding the power capsule for his spaceship which is disguised as a 1940’s diner. However, there are others with sinister plans in search of the diner and the surfer finds he must change the course of time. Cast includes Bruno Lawrence, Nique Needles, Ray Barrett and Max Gillies.

results.title: As tears go by
results.creator_credit: In-gear Film, Rover Tang and Wong
results.brief_description: Wong Kar-wai describes his first feature as ‘a tragedy set in the big city, focussing on several ordinary characters in a hopeless situation’. It has also been described as ‘an idiosyncratic riff on the plot and themes of Scorsese’s Mean Streets’. Ah Wah (Andy Lau) is an enigmatic hit man who, with his offsider Fly (Jacky Cheung), is, despite himself, dragged into trouble time and time again. The arrival of his cousin (Maggie Cheung) briefly offers hope of escape from the downward spiral. The emphasis is more on atmosphere and interplay between the three characters than upon plot. In Cantonese with English subtitles.

results.title: As our boyhood is...
results.brief_description: A documentary which studies the facilities for education - both good and bad - available to Afro-American children in the southern states of the USA during the mid-1940’s. An interesting documentary for its time for its sympathetic attitude towards the plight of Afro-American children in getting an education. Photography by Roger Barlow and Jospeh Braun.

results.title: As others see us: a look at interpersonal relations
results.creator_credit: Salenger Educational Media and Monte Young
results.brief_description: An animated film which examines self-image by feedback; exploring the reasons why people see us differently from how we see ourselves. Provides examples of how relationships can be improved by openness and how to obtain positive feedback to enhance effective communication and interpersonal relationships.
